# Halfpenny (British decimal coin)

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to: navigation, search

For the pre-decimal halfpenny coin, see [Halfpenny (British pre-decimal
coin)](/wiki/Halfpenny_\(British_pre-decimal_coin\) "Halfpenny \(British pre-
decimal coin\)").

The [British](/wiki/United_Kingdom "United Kingdom") decimal **halfpenny**
(**1 /2p**) coin was introduced in February 1971, at the time of
[decimalisation](/wiki/Decimal_Day "Decimal Day"), and was worth one two-
hundredth of a pound sterling. It was ignored in banking transactions, which
were carried out in units of 1p.

The decimal halfpenny had the same value as 1.2 pre-decimal pence, and was
introduced to enable the prices of some low-value items to be more accurately
translated to the new decimal currency. The possibility of setting prices
including an odd half penny also made it more practical to retain the pre-
decimal [sixpence](/wiki/British_sixpence_coin "British sixpence coin") in
circulation (with a value of 2 1/2 new pence) alongside the new decimal
coinage.

The halfpenny coin's obverse featured the profile of [Queen Elizabeth
II](/wiki/Queen_Elizabeth_II "Queen Elizabeth II"); the reverse featured an
image of [St Edward's Crown](/wiki/St_Edward%27s_Crown "St Edward's Crown").
It was minted in bronze (like the 1p and 2p coins). It was the smallest
decimal coin in both size and value. The size was in proportion to the 1p and
2p coins. It soon became Britain's least favourite coin.[1] [The
Treasury](/wiki/HM_Treasury "HM Treasury") had continued to argue that the
halfpenny was important in the fight against inflation (preventing prices from
being rounded up).[1] The coin was demonetised and [withdrawn from
circulation](/wiki/Withdrawal_of_low-denomination_coins "Withdrawal of low-
denomination coins") in December 1984.[1]

##
Design[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Halfpenny_\(British_decimal_coin\)&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Design")]

The [reverse](/wiki/Obverse_and_reverse "Obverse and reverse") of the coin,
designed by [Christopher Ironside](/wiki/Christopher_Ironside "Christopher
Ironside"), was a representation of [St Edward's
Crown](/wiki/St_Edward%27s_Crown "St Edward's Crown"), with the numeral "1/2"
below the crown, and either NEW PENNY (1971–1981) or HALF PENNY (1982–1984)
above the crown.

Only one design of [obverse](/wiki/Obverse "Obverse") was used on the
halfpenny coin. The inscription around the portrait on the obverse was
ELIZABETH II [D.G.REG.F.D.](/wiki/British_coinage#D.G.REG.F.D. "British
coinage") 19xx,[2] where 19xx was the year of minting. Both sides of the coin
are encircled by dots, a common feature on coins, known as beading.

As on all decimal coins produced before 1984, the portrait of [Queen Elizabeth
II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II") by [Arnold Machin](/wiki/Arnold_Machin
"Arnold Machin") appeared on the obverse;[3] in this portrait the Queen wears
the ['Girls of Great Britain and Ireland'
Tiara](/wiki/Girls_of_Great_Britain_and_Ireland_Tiara "Girls of Great Britain
and Ireland Tiara").

## Proposed quarter penny
coin[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Halfpenny_\(British_decimal_coin\)&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Proposed quarter penny coin")]

A decimal quarter-penny coin (to be struck in [aluminium](/wiki/Aluminium
"Aluminium")) was also proposed (which would have allowed the pre-decimal
[threepence](/wiki/History_of_the_threepence "History of the threepence") to
continue to circulate with a value of 1 1/4 new pence), but was never
produced.[5]
